item.description:
Look for endangered New England cottontails on this riverside wildlife area.

Located between Dover and Portsmouth on the western shore of the Bellamy River, the 400-acre Bellamy River Wildlife Management Area features a wide variety of land types and habitats--

 

-- the river and its banks, tidal creeks, salt and fresh water wetlands, grasslands, woodlands, and former agricultural fields.

The land is being actively managed to provide habitat for many animals including waterfowl and New England cottontails.

Time/Distance: We'll be out for about 2-3 hours, hiking on level, sometimes muddy ground. If there's snow on the ground, this is a great place to snowshoe!

Food & drinks afterward, probably at The Central Wave in Dover.

Directions: From Dover or from Route 4, take Back River Road to Rabbit Road. Turn right at end of Rabbit onto (Old) Garrison Road then left at the sign to the gate. (A portion of Back River Rd is called Piscataqua Rd on some maps.)

Trails on the 400-acre urban oasis are widely used by birders -particularly those seeking grassland species -- and other wildlife-watchers, hikers and cross-country skiers. Hunting and trapping are permitted.The Bellamy has been managed for wildlife since the early 1990s, after being acquired through the New Hampshire Land Conservation Investment Program (LCIP). Surrounded by urban communities, Bellamy is valued by its human neighbors for hunting, fishing and other outdoor opportunities -- and as a natural refuge for all kinds of wildlife. (Photo below: Jan 2010)

The Bellamy River WMA lies within the Atlantic Flyway, so black ducks, Canada geese and even coots (old & young ones) frequent the area. It's a major feeding and resting area for these and other migrating waterfowl, plus estuarine and shorebird species such as sandpipers, herons, gulls, and osprey. Other wildlife include deer, pheasant, upland game, bobolinks, and meadowlarks.

A project is underway to re-establish native grasslands at Bellamy River WMA. A commercial timber sale/habitat improvement project was recently completed to create patches and strip cuts to regenerate oak, provide woody browse and increase structural habitat diversity.

Winter Hiking: This time of year it's a good idea to carry microspikes and/or hiking poles because trails can be wet or icy even if there's no snow on the ground.

Liability Release - AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, YOU AGREE TO hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer and his heirs, and all members and participants of the Seacoast Outdoors Meetup group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Kayaking, camping, hiking, bicycling, snow sports and other activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment.

Time and location are subject to change due to weather and other factors.  Always check email & this listing for updates before leaving home.
item.name: Cottontail Hike @ Bellamy River Wildlife Area
